resources.string: One of Tucson\'s own, it is a place where you can meet up with friends or have a business meeting over an overstuffed sandwich. Baked goods and fresh bread are always available, along with seasonal offerings.

Either as a stopover for the nearby indie filmhouse, the Loft Cinema, or functioning as a working class bar to catch up on the games, the Red Garter provides service mixed with cheap drinks and tasty food.
In the overcrowded field of fast Mexican food joints, the Taco Shop stands out for its long hours and speedy service. Plus, its good food is a plus, too.
Visit the Back Dough at the back of the restaurant for freshly baked pies.
Try the BBQ Burger and the $2 PBR.
A chimichanga meal will fill you up for the entire day... in a good way.

Situated well west of the city itself, the Desert Museum is a showcase of many of the flora and fauna of the Sonoran Desert. During the summers, the muesum is also open at night to show off its nocturnal residents.

The Saguaro National Monument is split into its west and east sides. On the east, cars can drive through and see the natural scenery or get off to walk through it as well. On the west in the Santa Rita mountains, you can see an unrivaled sunset or go for a hike.

From aardvarks to zebras, the Reid Park Zoo has been nationally recognized for its welcoming atmosphere and care of its animals. The pride of the zoo most recently has come in its recently built elephant habitat.
Come early to beat the heat and the crowds.
Bring a set of hiking shoes, a camera, and plenty of time (and water).
Come at 10:00am to hand feed the giraffes.
Meet all the cultures that make Tucson
Honor Vietnam veterans with classic rock
The national\'s largest celebration of books
Bringing together dozens of cultures and their foods, Tucson Meet Yourself meets twice a year to remind Tucson\'s nearly one million residents that we share a common home and we really love to eat.
What was once an informal gathering of Vietnam veterans has turned to a classic rock bonanza harkening back to better memories of the 60\'s and 70\'s while never forgetting the tougher memories, too.

Recently started by the University of Arizona, the Tucson Festival of Books brings together authors, readers, and everyone in between in a celebration of all things books. Activities for writers and children are so plentiful that the local paper publishes a multipage guide on it every year.
Bring at least $40 in pocket cash, because you will want to taste everything.
If you\'re too late to park in the park, the nearby neighborhoods don\'t mind you parking in the sidestreets.
Schedule out which events you want to attend, as there are maany happening at the same time.
Intimate venue for today\'s hottest artists

The historic Club Congress has been with Tucson for almost 90 years, long enough to have John Dillinger himself arrested right outside its doors (\"Well, I\'ll be damned,\" he was quoted at the time). Everything from dancing to drag shows to fundraisers to video game competitions are held here.

The Loft Cinema has recently become a non-profit and because of this move it has allowed itself to become a fearless place showing any kind of movie that a major run theater won\'t. Mondo Mondays, Cult Classic Fridays, and free summer movies for children are just a small sampling of their events and dedication to the community.

Right across the street from Club Congress is Tucson\'s pride, the Rialto Theater. Music acts of all kinds have come through their doors, and with each major act they erect a wallside mural on the side of their building in their honor.
Come weekend mornings for bloody mary specials or just a tasty brunch with a cup of coffee.
Come to the First Friday Shorts to watch the community\'s best short films... and gong them.
The Korean/Mexican food truck that parks just outside on Saturdays is the most amazing food ever made or eaten.
